title: ‘Vicksburg’ Review: Breaking the Confederacy
text: The first week in July 1863 was disastrous for the Confederacy. The Battle of Gettysburg, ending July 3, was, as we know, a great Union victory. Lee’s Army of Northern Virginia was forced to retreat from Pennsylvania and would never again be on the offensive. The Eastern theater would soon turn into a slow, bloody war of attrition, one that the South, with inferior resources, couldn’t hope to win militarily. The taking of Vicksburg, Miss., on July 4, 1863, by Ulysses S. Grant’s Army of the Tennessee, was a smaller campaign, if measured by the number of troops involved and the number of casualties. But it was equally momentous,...
description: “The Yankees . . . are worse than the Goth and Vandals of the middle ages,” wrote one Confederate soldier. The feeling was mutual.
